subject: RE: [junit] JUnit question
msgSnippet: Marcy... I do not have any information on automating the process, but I strongly recommend you check out Working Effectively With Legacy Code   by Michael
messageBody:
Marcy...

I do not have any information on automating the process, but I strongly
recommend you check out Working Effectively With Legacy Code by Michael
Feathers
(http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/0131177052/qid=1127231592/sr=
8-1/ref=pd_bbs_1/104-6363961-7787107?v=glance
<http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/0131177052/qid=1127231592/sr=
8-1/ref=pd_bbs_1/104-6363961-7787107?v=glance&s=books&n=507846>
&s=books&n=507846).

Unless your code was designed for testing, it is likely to have a lot of
dependencies that will make testing difficult. The book gives a lot of
techniques for breaking such dependencies.

God luck,


--
Jim McMaster
mailto:jim.mcmaster@...






_____

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Marcy Spector
Sent: Monday, September 19, 2005 12:46 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] JUnit question


Hello,

We are facing a situation at our company of having to
create JUnit tests for developed code. Maybe we
should have followed a better methodology (which can
be another email thread), but the situation is we have
lots of unit testing to write.

What are some ways and/or products to either try to
automate such a task or implement some best practice
at this stage?

Better yet, is JUnit automation possible or practical?

Thanks!

__________________________________________________
